articles.description:

articles.description:
ABUJA, May 24 (IPS) - Nigeria’s accountant-general, the administrative head of the country’s treasury, has been arrested by the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission for allegedly stealing 80 billion naira ($134 million). This is a staggering theft in a country that has an estimated poverty rate of 95 million (48% of the population) and some of the worst health indices in the world.

Read the full story, “Corruption Kills”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Corruption Kills

articles.description:
Durban, May 24 (IPS) - Lucky Agbavor sleeps on a mattress in a church in Accra, Ghana sells juice to earn an income, and has been a child labourer since he was four. Now he has made his way onto the international stage, participating in the 5th Global Conference on the Elimination of Child labour.

Read the full story, “Former Child Labourer Free Quality Education Key to Ending Child Labour”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Former Child Labourer Free Quality Education Key to Ending Child Labour

articles.description:
Time is short for Sudan to reach a solution to its protracted political crisis, the Special Representative for the country told the Security Council on Tuesday, warning that if the impasse is not urgently overcome, the consequences will be felt beyond national borders, impacting a whole generation.

Read the full story, “Time is short for Sudan to resolve political crisis, Mission chief warns”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Time is short for Sudan to resolve political crisis, Mission chief warns

articles.description:

articles.description:
The Member States of the World Health Organization (WHO) on Tuesday, re-elected Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus to serve a second five-year term as Director-General of the world’s leading public health agency.

articles.title: Tedros re-elected to lead the World Health Organization

articles.description:
BUENOS AIRES, May 24 (IPS) - "All we ever wanted was to keep working. And although we have not gotten to where we would like to be, we know that we can," says Edith Pereira, a short energetic woman, as she walks through the corridors of Farmacoop, in the south of the Argentine capital. She proudly says it is "the first pharmaceutical laboratory in the world recovered by its workers."

Read the full story, “Employee-run Companies, Part of the Landscape of an Argentina in Crisis”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Employee-run Companies, Part of the Landscape of an Argentina in Crisis

articles.description:
In their red school uniforms, with backpacks on their heads to protect from falling debris, More than 200 students and teachers from Tanjong Benoa Elementary School on the Indonesian island of Bali, filed calmly up three flights of stairs to the rooftop of a hotel, close to their classrooms.

articles.title: Deputy UN chief praises resilience of Bali students in face of disaster threats

articles.description:
MADRID, May 24 (IPS) - The message is clear: three-quarters of the world’s population will be affected by drought by 2050. Does it sound too far in time? Well, your kids might be among the billions of humans living on a desertified planet.

Read the full story, “The Risks of Turning Planet Earth into a Giant Desert”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Risks of Turning Planet Earth into a Giant Desert

articles.author: Advertising partner
articles.description: [Sponsored Article]  The Hong Kong Institute for Advanced Study (HKIAS) at City University of Hong Kong (CityU) continues to connect scholars around the globe, allowing them to explore interdisciplinary ideas and address real-world issues.   The most recent HKIAS Distinguished Lecture Series on Electronics and Photonics, held in March and April, was  supported in part by Kwang Hua Educational Foundation. The discussion topics covered nanotechnology, antenna design, 6G networks and much more, with five leading scientists outlining the latest research and potential applications of breakthrough technologies. The series attracted an international audience of over 2,000 scholars and guests.     The power of plasmonic biosensors    Nanotechnology and its biosensor applications are becoming ever more prevalent in the field of biomedical microsystems.   Kicking things off on March 1, Professor Stella W. Pang, Head of the Department of Electrical Engineering and Director of the Centre for Biosystems, Neuroscience, and Nanotechnology at CityU, spoke about “Nanotechnology for High-Performance Devices and Sensors”.     Noting the increased use of plasmonic sensors, she explained the ability of nanoimprint technology “to generate a large area of nanostructures within a few seconds”, showing high reproducibility and throughput. The novel 3D multiple layer plasmonic biosensors exhibit enhanced electric fields and a much higher sensitivity. This made it possible to detect lung cancer A549 live cells and nanoscale DNAs at very low concentrations by monitoring the highly sensitive resonance peak shift.   Also, hybrid coupling of plasmonic and photonic crystal modes leads to a record high sensitivity of 1376 nm/refractive index unit. “Combining these biosensors with 3D engineered platforms, we can separate cancer cells from normal cells for identification, which will further improve the sensitivity such that cancer patients could be diagnosed at a much earlier stage, potentially saving millions of lives,”…
articles.title: Advances in electronics and photonics herald a new era

articles.description:
Farmers harvest wheat on the outskirts of Jammu, India, on April 30. A recent heat wave has affected the yield of India’s wheat crops. | Xinhua News Agency via Getty Images
    

  
Trade is vital to mitigating the global food crisis.
 Two weeks ago, India, the world’s second-largest producer of wheat by volume, announced export restrictions on the commodity. India’s wheat farmers are facing an estimated loss of 15 to 20 percent of their crop due to a devastating heat wave, and the government cited concerns about domestic food security in explaining the move. 
While India’s wheat only represents a small percentage of global wheat exports and the government announced that it still plans to export to countries in need, the restrictions are only the latest in a distressing global trend that, …
articles.title: Countries are limiting food exports. It may make global hunger worse.

articles.description:
That's a lot of guns. | (William West/AFP/Getty Images)
    

  
In the wake of the killing in Uvalde, here’s what America can learn from Australia’s response to tragedy.
 Tuesday’s shooting in Uvalde, Texas, has already kicked off another national debate about gun control. It is worth considering, as one piece of evidence about what policies do and do not work, the experience of Australia in the late 1990s. 
Between October 1996 and September 1997, Australia responded to its own gun violence problem with a solution that was both straightforward and severe: It collected roughly 650,000 privately held guns. It was one of the largest mandatory gun buyback programs in recent history.
And there’s decent reason to think it worked. That does not mean that something even remotely similar would wo…
articles.title: Australia confiscated 650,000 guns. Murders and suicides plummeted.

articles.description: UKRAINE's invasion by Russia may be the beginning of the "World War Three" and our civilization "may not be able to survive it", said billionaire financier George Soros in a stark warning while speaking at his annual dinner at the World Economic Forum in Davos.
articles.title: Warning as Putin’s attack on Ukraine may launch ‘World War Three’ - 'May not survive it'

articles.description: JOE BIDEN has delivered a statement from the White House after at least 18 children and one adult were killed in a Texas school shooting.
articles.title: Texas shooting: Joe Biden calls for action on gun laws following school 'massacre'

articles.description: ANGELA MERKEL has been blasted by philanthropist George Soros for "special deals" she made with Moscow which enabled Europe to become dependent on Russian gas.
articles.title: Angela Merkel's 'special deals' with Moscow blamed for Europe's dependence on Russian gas

articles.description: VLADIMIR PUTIN's war in Donbas has been blasted by President Volodymyr Zelensky as the Ukrainian leader fears the Russian fighters will leave nothing behind.
articles.title: 'They want to destroy everything' Zelensky issues warning as battle for Donbas rages on

articles.description: MORE RUSSIAN TROOPS have reportedly been accused of war crimes during the conflict in Ukraine.
articles.title: Eight more Russian troops accused of 'torturing and killing civilians' in criminal case

articles.description: Fifteen people, including a teacher, have been shot dead at an elementary school in Texas, according to reports.
articles.title: Texas school shooting: 15 dead including multiple children as students rushed to hospital

articles.description: RUSSIA remains embedded in Ukrainian territory, where Vladimir Putin's forces hope to complete a landmark operation in their campaign. Egils Levits, the President of Latvia, along Ukraine's border to the west, has discussed NATO's options for stopping Russia in its tracks.
articles.title: 'Russia is provoked by weakness!' How a NATO 'brigade' could force Putin's hand

articles.description: RUSSIA's next move in Vladimir Putin's push to seize the Donbas from Ukraine has been mapped out by a US military analyst.
articles.title: 'Trying to cut off the rail supply' Russian military's next move in Donbas spelt out

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The gunman in the Texas elementary school massacre barged unchallenged through an unlocked door, then killed 19 children and two teachers while holed up in their classroom for an hour before a tactical team stormed in and killed him, police said on Thursday.
articles.title: Officials say Texas gunman entered unimpeded as anger mounts over police response

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: China and Russia on Thursday vetoed tougher United Nations sanctions against North Korea, rejecting a US effort to punish Pyongyang for testing an intercontinental ballistic missile.
articles.title: China, Russia veto US-led push for tougher sanctions on North Korea

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Senegal’s President Macky Sall fired his health minister on Thursday as his country mourned the death of 11 newborn babies in a hospital fire blamed on an electrical short circuit.
articles.title: Senegalese president fires health minister after deadly hospital fire

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Unstoppable world number one Iga Swiatek racked up her 30th successive victory at the French Open on Thursday as 2021 runner-up Stefanos Tsitsipas survived another Roland Garros rollercoaster.
articles.title: Swiatek cruises, Tsitsipas hangs on at Roland Garros day five

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Andy “Fletch” Fletcher, keyboardist for British synth pop giants Depeche Mode for more than 40 years, has died at age 60.
articles.title: Depeche Mode keyboard player Andy Fletcher dies at 60

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Ray Liotta, the blue-eyed actor best known for playing mobster Henry Hill in “Goodfellas” and baseball player Shoeless Joe Jackson in “Field of Dreams,” has died. He was 67
articles.title: Ray Liotta, 'Goodfellas' star, dies at 67

articles.author: Benjamin DODMAN
articles.description: India’s prolific movie industry enjoyed pride of place at the Cannes Film Festival, starring as the film market’s first-ever guest of honour. FRANCE 24 spoke to director Shaunak Sen about his stunning New Delhi-set documentary “All That Breathes”, which screened at the festival this week.
articles.title: ‘Front-row seats to the apocalypse’: Cannes doc takes on Delhi pollution, sectarian violence

articles.author: David GORMEZANO
articles.description: With Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, nuclear facilities have been caught up in the midst of conventional warfare for the first time in history. That nightmare scenario is one that few of the industry’s players had anticipated. In Chernobyl and Zaporizhzhia, Russian forces represent a lingering threat to the most basic rules of nuclear security.
articles.title: Should the war in Ukraine spur a nuclear security rethink?

articles.author: Alexia KEFALAS
articles.description: Cypriot President Nikos Anastasiadis granted an interview to FRANCE 24 from the capital Nicosia. The northern third of the Republic of Cyprus has been under Turkish domination since 1974. Anastasiadis said that Russia's invasion of Ukraine uses the "exact same arguments that Turkey used to invade Cyprus". Asked about tensions with Turkey over hydrocarbons, he expressed hope that Ankara will not "will not attempt to do anything that will cause conflagration and risk peace in the region".
articles.title: Cyprus's president sees parallel between Turkish and Russian 'revisionism'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Suspected jihadists killed around 50 civilians in Burkina Faso, the Eastern region's governor said Thursday, in the latest attack in the impoverished Sahel nation.
articles.title: Suspected jihadists kill dozens in eastern Burkina Faso

articles.author: Kate MOODY
articles.description: This year's World Economic Forum in Davos has been dominated by the war in Ukraine and its implications on the global economy. With the drop in grain exports from the region, concern is growing over a looming food crisis. FRANCE 24's Business Editor Kate Moody spoke to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva, who criticised food export restrictions by countries such as India for "only making a crisis worse". She also called for governments to help "speed up" agricultural production "where this is still possible".
articles.title: Davos 2022: IMF chief says food export bans 'only making crisis worse'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The Palestinian Authority on Thursday announced the results of its investigation into the shooting death of Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh, saying it had proven she was deliberately killed by Israeli forces as she tried to flee.
articles.title: Palestinian probe finds Israel deliberately killed Al Jazeera journalist

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: French President Emmanuel Macron asked his Turkish counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Thursday to "respect the sovereign choice" of Finland and Sweden to join NATO.
articles.title: Macron urges Turkey to respect ‘sovereign choice’ of Finland, Sweden on NATO

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Law enforcement authorities faced questions and criticism Thursday over how much time elapsed before they stormed an Uvalde elementary school classroom and put a stop to the rampage by a gunman who killed 19 children and two teachers.
articles.title: ‘Go in there!’: Parents of Texas school shooting victims question police delays

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The British government unveiled a multibillion-pound package Thursday to ease a severe cost-of-living squeeze, announcing the plan a day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed to “move on” from a months-long scandal over parties in government buildings during COVID-19 lockdowns.
articles.title: UK govt, reeling from ‘partygate’, announces financial aid package

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The former president of the Louvre museum in Paris has been charged with conspiring to hide the origin of Egyptian archaeological treasures that investigators suspect were spirited out of the country during the Arab Spring uprisings, a French judicial source said Thursday.
articles.title: Former president of Louvre museum charged in art trafficking case

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Pakistan's ousted prime minister Imran Khan disbanded a protest march by supporters on Thursday after clashes with police outside parliament the previous evening, but he warned that they would return unless an election was called within six days.
articles.title: Pakistan's ex-PM Imran Khan issues election ultimatum after protest march

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt on Wednesday signed into law the strictest abortion ban in the United States, one that prohibits abortions from fertilization and allows private citizens to sue those who help women terminate their pregnancies.
articles.title: Oklahoma signs into law strictest abortion ban in the US

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Russian forces shelled Kharkiv, killing nine people on Thursday after Moscow’s bid to capture Ukraine’s second city was repelled early in the war. Further south, fighting in the Donbas region reached of “maximum intensity”, according to a senior Ukrainian defence official. Read about the day’s events as they unfolded on our liveblog. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: Russia shells Kharkiv, war in Donbas reaches ‘maximum intensity’

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Tunisian President Kais Saied issued on Wednesday a decree to call voters to a referendum on a new constitution on July 25, the official gazette said, ignoring the opposition's calls to reverse the controversial move.
articles.title: Tunisian president issues decree to hold referendum on new constitution

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Eleven newborn babies died in a hospital fire in the western Senegalese city of Tivaouane, the president of the country said late Wednesday.
articles.title: Senegal: 11 newborn babies die in hospital fire, says president

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Spanish teenage sensation Carlos Alcaraz and third seed Alexander Zverev both saved a match point in five-set French Open thrillers, while 13-time winner Rafael Nadal and reigning champion Novak Djokovic eased into the third round Wednesday.
articles.title: Nadal easily wins 300th Grand Slam match as Alcaraz, Zverev squeak through

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Four bombs ripped through minibuses and a mosque in Afghanistan on Wednesday, killing at least 12 people, officials said, with at least some of the attacks claimed by the Islamic State group.
articles.title: Four bomb attacks kill at least 12 in Afghanistan

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Nicolo Zaniolo won Roma their first ever major European trophy on Wednesday with the only goal in a 1-0 win over Feyenoord in the inaugural Europa Conference League final.
articles.title: Roma beat Feyenoord 1-0 to win first-ever Europa Conference League

articles.author: Eve JACKSON
articles.description: He became an overnight star with the TV series "Normal People", which came out while many of us were lockdown in our homes. Irish actor Paul Mescal is in Cannes with two films at this year's festival. One of them is "Aftersun", a rare father and daughter drama directed by Scottish filmmaker Charlotte Wells. The pair sat down with FRANCE 24's Eve Jackson.
articles.title: Cannes 2022: 'Normal People' star Paul Mescal on his role in 'Aftersun'

articles.author: Benjamin DODMAN
articles.description: The devastating physical and psychological toll of war in Ukraine was laid bare on Wednesday in Maksym Nakonechny’s “Butterfly Vision”, the latest work to focus on Ukraine’s plight at the Cannes Film Festival, where talk of war and calls for a boycott of all things Russian have dominated discussions from day one.
articles.title: War films, protests and Russia boycotts: How Ukraine’s plight shaped Cannes 2022

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Desperation turned to heart-wrenching sorrow for families of grade schoolers killed after an 18-year-old gunman barricaded himself in their Texas classroom and began shooting, killing at least 19 children and their two teachers.
articles.title: Desperation turns into sorrow in the aftermath of Texas school shooting

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Digging among the rubble of destroyed buildings, Ukrainian servicemen and volunteers are engaged in a gruesome task: gathering the bodies of dead Russian soldiers. So far they have collected around 60 bodies in Ukraine's Kharkiv region, where Russian forces have retreated in recent weeks, stacking them in a refrigerated rail carriage. It is hoped that the bodies may be exchanged for Ukrainian war prisoners.
articles.title: Ukrainian army and volunteers gather Russian dead from Kharkiv rubble

articles.author: Sébastian SEIBT
articles.description: Hacked files revealing the repression of Uighur Muslims in China were published on Tuesday by a consortium of media. Labeled the “Xinjiang Police Files”, these documents owe a lot to one man in particular: Adrian Zenz. In recent years, this German anthropologist has become a central target of Chinese propaganda for his work on the ethnic group’s living conditions.
articles.title: Adrian Zenz, the academic behind the ‘Xinjiang Police Files’, on China's abuse of Uighurs

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Hundreds of protesters from a radical leftist party in South Africa marched Wednesday on the French embassy in Pretoria to demand that France leave Africa.
articles.title: Protesters from far-left South Africa party tell France to 'get out of Africa'

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Pakistan's ousted prime minister Imran Khan on Wednesday led a convoy of thousands of supporters towards the capital Islamabad in a show of force the new government has attempted to shut down, with clashes breaking out between police and protesters.
articles.title: Ousted Pakistan PM Khan leads protest march on blockaded Islamabad

articles.description: On May 19, female television hosts and journalists working in Afghan broadcasting received a new order from the Taliban: “Cover your face”. Our Observer, an Afghan TV presenter, explains how she received the order and how Afghan journalists have been resisting the Taliban’s resolve to “remove women from society”.
articles.title: Taliban enforces burqa for female journalists: ‘We are the last ones resisting’

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: US pharmaceutical giant Pfizer on Wednesday said it would sell its patented drugs on a not-for-profit basis to the world's poorest countries, as part of a new initiative announced at the World Economic Forum in Davos.
articles.title: Pfizer offers to sell medicines to poorest countries on not-for-profit basis

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: A "humbled" Boris Johnson said he took full responsibility but would not quit after a damning official report on Wednesday detailed a series of illegal lockdown parties at the British leader's Downing Street office.
articles.title: Johnson takes responsibility for lockdown-era Number 10 parties – but won't quit

articles.author: Genie GODULA
articles.description: Over two thirds of young Colombians say their lives have got worse over the past year, which saw a fierce crackdown on anti-government protests in a country still recovering from five decades of conflict. Six years after the peace deal with the FARC rebels, many young people are backing the former mayor of Bogota, Gustavo Petro, in the May 29 presidential election. If he wins, Petro would become Colombia's first-ever leftist leader. In this special edition of Inside the Americas, we meet several young Colombians who are hoping for change.
articles.title: Special programme: Colombia's peace deal generation

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces has reached the limits of the key eastern Ukraine city of Severodonetsk, the regional governor said Wednesday, describing the combat as "very difficult". Follow FRANCE 24's liveblog for the latest developments. All times are Paris time (GMT+2).
articles.title: Live: Fighting reaches 'outskirts' of key east Ukraine city Severodonetsk

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: China faced new accusations Tuesday that it was sanctioning abuses of Uyghurs at the "highest levels", as a vast document leak came out during a controversial visit by the UN rights chief.
articles.title: UN rights chief visits China as leaked files show abuse of Uyghur Muslims

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: An Iraqi man who came to the United States two years ago and applied for asylum hatched a plot to assassinate former President George W. Bush in retaliation for casualties against his compatriots during the Iraq war, the U.S. government announced Tuesday.
articles.title: Feds: Iraqi living in Ohio plotted assassination of George W. Bush

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Stefanos Tsitsipas came back from the brink to reach the French Open second round as Roland Garros was again overshadowed by the crisis engulfing Wimbledon.
articles.title: French Open: Tsitsipas, Medvedev make it to second round

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: North Korea fired three ballistic missiles off its east coast on Wednesday, Seoul's military said, just hours after US President Joe Biden left the region following a trip in which he agreed to boost measures to deter the nuclear-armed state.
articles.title: North Korea launches three ballistic missiles hours after Biden leaves Asia

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: A teenage gunman opened fire at an elementary school in South Texas on Tuesday, killing 18 children and three adults before the suspect was also killed, officials said, in the latest spasm of mass gun violence sweeping the United States.
articles.title: Biden takes aim at gun lobby after Texas elementary school mass shooting

articles.description: The Ukrainian town of Bucha, the site of alleged mass killings by Russian forces, remains riddled with memories of occupation – from bullet holes to destroyed homes. To help Bucha’s residents move on from the “horror” of the Russian invasion, a Canadian volunteer of Ukrainian descent has begun turning bullet holes into things of beauty, in order to bring joy and smiles back to the people of Ukraine.
articles.title: ‘We will bloom again’: How one woman is turning bullet holes in Ukraine into works of art

articles.author: David RICH
articles.description: Cannes delves into the traumatic aftermath of the November 13, 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris with French movies “November” and “Paris Memories” – one charting the hunt for the perpetrators, the other exploring survivors’ efforts to overcome the trauma.
articles.title: Cannes Film Festival revisits trauma of 2015 terror attacks in Paris

articles.author: Cyrielle CABOT
articles.description: With a slumping birth rate, a death rate on the rise and immigration slowly falling, Russia is experiencing population decline. Despite having launched some of the most encouraging childbirth policies, Putin is now facing a “major problem for someone who believes population is synonymous with power”, says French demographer Laurent Chalard.
articles.title: Population decline in Russia: ‘Putin has no other choice but to win’ in Ukraine

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, a former Australian Open runner-up and world number five, bid an emotional goodbye to tennis at Roland Garros on Tuesday after losing in the first round to Casper Ruud.
articles.title: France’s Tsonga bids emotional farewell to tennis career after French Open loss

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Every Saturday for the past seven weeks, a former factory in central Kyiv has been hosting a "tattoo marathon", with dozens of locals getting inked in a show of support for the country's war effort. All proceeds are donated to Ukrainian forces fighting on the front lines.
articles.title: 'Symbol of courage': Kyiv tattoo marathon raises money for Ukrainian forces

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: World number two Daniil Medvedev eased into the French Open second round on Tuesday but he could not escape the shadow of Wimbledon, the Grand Slam tournament where he has been declared persona non grata.
articles.title: Russia’s Medvedev sails into French Open round two as players debate Wimbledon

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: A French NGO has called for protests Tuesday against what it called a “government of shame” after a newly appointed government minister was accused of rape and sexual assault by two women. Damien Abad, France’s new minister of social services, the elderly and the disabled, becomes the latest government minister to be facing sexual assault allegations.
articles.title: 'Government of shame': French minister accused of rape, sparking calls for protest

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus was re-elected Tuesday for a second five-year term as head of the World Health Organization, following a secret ballot.
articles.title: World Health Organization chief Tedros easily re-elected for five-year term

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: The Islamic State (IS) group appears to be stepping up attacks close to the border between Mali and Niger, with sources suggesting that the jihadists are trying to seize control of the border itself. FRANCE 24’s terrorism expert Wassim Nasr explains.
articles.title: Islamic State group ‘trying to control’ Mali-Niger border with series of attacks

articles.description: The Duchess of Sussex placed white flowers tied with a purple ribbon at a memorial outside the Uvalde County Courthouse on Thursday.
articles.title: Meghan Markle visits Texas to pay respect to school shooting victims

articles.description: Gun safety groups are urging Biden to make an emergency declaration on gun violence, name a gun violence czar and issue more executive orders as lawmakers stall.
articles.title: As Biden is pressed to act on gun control, White House says it’s up to Congress

articles.author: Michelle Karlenzig
articles.description: Kyrylo and Anastasiia Ovcharenko landed two weeks ago in Winnipeg after fleeing Ukraine - and they say the support so far has been incredible.
articles.title: “It just seemed like fate,” Manitoba woman wants more people to host Ukrainian refugees

articles.description: The move came amid growing pressure on the department, which came under scrutiny following a scathing report by the inspector general last July.
articles.title: FBI agents accused of botching Larry Nassar abuse probe will not be charged: U.S. DOJ

articles.description: The officers who initially arrived on the scene pursued the gunman into the school, but soon after had to take cover when the shooter began opening fire on them, an official said.
articles.title: Shooter entered Texas school unobstructed, police say as questions rise over response

articles.description: A series of other deaths also have raised concerns about maternal and infant health in the West African nation known for having some of the best hospitals in the region.
articles.title: 11 newborn babies killed in Senegal hospital fire, president says

articles.description: The U.S.-led resolution would have reduced exports of crude oil and petroleum products to North Korea and banned the North from exporting mineral fuels, oils and waxes.
articles.title: China, Russia veto new UN sanctions on North Korea over renewed missile launches

articles.author: Sean Boynton
articles.description: Joe Garcia died at home Thursday morning, according to the family of Grade 4 teacher Irma Garcia, who was among the 21 people killed in Tuesday's massacre in Uvalde, Texas.
articles.title: Husband of Texas school shooting victim dies of heart attack, family says

articles.description: Canada's Transport Minister Omar Alghabra says he is positive about the future of Canada and the U.S. automotive partnership after meeting with the Biden administration.
articles.title: Positive shift in Canada-U.S. relations after D.C. meetings, transport minister says

articles.author: Aaron D’Andrea
articles.description: Mass shootings like the ones in Texas and Buffalo can trigger traumatic memories of those watching abroad, experts say. With these events becoming more common, how do we cope?
articles.title: Texas, Buffalo killings join growing list of mass shootings. How do we cope?

articles.author: Irelyne Lavery
articles.description: Of the nineteen children and two teachers killed, the victims include a “loving 10-year-old little boy” and “adventurous” teacher who was a caring mother and wife.
articles.title: Everything we know so far about the Texas mass school shooting

articles.author: Kayla Guerrette
articles.description: The tragedy in Texas also hitting close to home as many parents and teachers are wondering how to explain something that just doesn't make sense.
articles.title: Saskatchewan parents and teachers navigating Texas tragedy

articles.description: By now it's as predictable as the calls for thoughts and prayers: A mass shooting leaves many dead, and wild conspiracy theories and misinformation about the carnage soon follow.
articles.title: Misinformation and conspiracy theories spiral after Texas mass school shooting

articles.description: State lawmakers approved the ban enforced by civil lawsuits rather than criminal prosecution, similar to a Texas law that was passed last year.
articles.title: Oklahoma ban on nearly all abortions signed into law, becoming strictest in U.S.

articles.author: Marney Blunt
articles.description: The mass shooting at an elementary school in Texas is an unspeakable tragedy, but it's one that needs to be spoken about with your kids, experts say.
articles.title: ‘Hatred doesn’t steal our hope’: Helping children understand, cope with Texas school shooting

articles.author: Irelyne Lavery
articles.description: Police in the Texas have arrested a suspect after he was seen with what appeared to be a rifle walking towards a Richardson, Texas, high school.
articles.title: Student caught with firearms outside Texas high school day after deadly shooting

articles.description: Police deployed in force and three youths were detained after an employee at a school in Germany reported having seen a youth carrying a firearm in a basement room of the building.
articles.title: Three students detained after reports of firearm at German school

articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin early last month signed a decree introducing visa restrictions for citizens of countries that Moscow deems "unfriendly," including Ukraine.
articles.title: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy orders end to visa-free travel for Russians: ‘Important and vital’

articles.description: Putin's decree applying to the Kherson and Zaporizhzhia regions could allow Russia to strengthen its hold on territory that lies between eastern Ukraine.
articles.title: Russia plans to strengthen army, ease citizenship for residents of occupied Ukraine

articles.author: Amanda Connolly
articles.description: Tempers flared at a press conference Wednesday about the Robb Elementary School shooting when Beto O’Rourke, the former U.S. Representative for Texas, confronted authorities.
articles.title: Here are 4 gun reform policies U.S. advocates say could reduce violence

articles.description: Russia is attempting to seize the separatist-claimed Donbas' two provinces, Donetsk and Luhansk, and trap Ukrainian forces in a pocket on the main eastern front.
articles.title: Russian forces seek to put stranglehold on Ukrainian twin cities

articles.author: Sean Boynton
articles.description: "Our kids are living in fear every single time they set foot in a classroom because they think they're going to be next," said Democratic Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut.
articles.title: Calls grow for U.S. gun control after Texas school shooting: ‘Our kids are living in fear’

articles.author: Irelyne Lavery
articles.description: State and local officials in the small city of Uvalde confirmed the 18-year-old shooter was dead and there was no longer a threat to public safety.
articles.title: At least 21 dead after shooting at Texas elementary school: officials

articles.description: Germany has ordered 40,000 doses of a vaccine to be ready to vaccinate contacts of those infected with monkeypox if an outbreak in Germany becomes more severe.
articles.title: Germany orders 40,000 vaccine doses as precaution against spread of monkeypox

articles.author: Aaron D’Andrea
articles.description: Tuesday marked three months of full-scale conflict between Russia and Ukraine with no signs of the war nearing an end. Can Ukraine emerge victorious?
articles.title: Russia ‘running out of ideas’ in 3-month-old war. Can Ukraine win?

articles.author: Amanda Connolly
articles.description: Defence Minister Anita Anand said a shipment of artillery rounds, part of a $98-million aid package to Ukraine, will work will any of the weapons being shared by NATO allies.
articles.title: Canada sending 20K rounds of artillery to Ukraine as Russia invasion hits 3-month mark

articles.description: The director general of the WHO, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, was reappointed to a second five-year term Tuesday by the U.N. health agency's member countries.
articles.title: WHO chief Tedros to lead U.N health agency for second five-year term

articles.author: Kathryn Mannie
articles.description: A video of the confrontation was posted to Facebook. After pastor John Lowe II admitted to adultery in front of his congregation, a woman took the mic to dispute his story.
articles.title: Pastor admits ‘adultery’ in church with then-16-year-old member of congregation

articles.description: Taiwan loomed over a Tokyo meeting of leaders of the Quad grouping of the U.S., Japan, Australia and India, who stressed their determination to ensure a free Indo-Pacific region.
articles.title: Biden says no change to ‘strategic ambiguity’ on Taiwan despite U.S. intervention remark

articles.description: Kharkiv came under intense Russian bombardment following Moscow's Feb. 24 invasion, forcing thousands of civilians to flee to the depths of the metro.
articles.title: Ukrainians sheltering in Kharkiv metro stations begin to leave as service resumes

sources.title: The Seattle Times World – The Seattle Times

articles.author: Daniel Politi
articles.description: Chile’s president publicly apologized to a woman who was sterilized without her consent at a public hospital two decades ago because she was HIV-positive.
articles.title: Chile apologizes to woman forcibly sterilized for HIV status

articles.author: Anton Troianovski
articles.description: Looming over the debate is the biggest unknown: whether President Vladimir Putin of Russia would be willing to accept anything other than total capitulation by Ukraine.
articles.title: After months of war in Ukraine, a burning question: How could it end?

articles.author: ANDREA RODRIGUEZ and MILEXSY DURAN
articles.description: Some of the more than 840 Haitians who tried to reach the United States in a boat but ended up in Cuba say Thursday that they fled violence in their country and were charged thousands of dollars by smugglers who ushered them onto a dilapidated boat and later abandoned them at sea.
articles.title: ‘No future for babies:’ 842 US-bound Haitians end up in Cuba

articles.author: BOUAZZA BEN BOUAZZA
articles.description: The International Organization for Migration says up to 600 people attempting to reach Europe by sea from Tunisia and Libya have gone missing during the first three months of 2022.
articles.title: IOM: Up to 600 missing at sea in 3 months in Central Med

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: Poland's lawmakers have approved the removal of a disciplinary body of the top court that the right-wing government has used to sanction outspoken judges, drawing condemnation from the European Union.
articles.title: Polish lawmakers back removing judicial body EU criticized

articles.author: ASHIFA KASSAM
articles.description: Spain’s parliament has voted to approve a bill that makes consent a key determinant in sexual assault cases, freeing victims of having to prove that violence or intimidation was used against them.
articles.title: Spain: Parliament backs “Only yes means yes” consent bill

articles.author: Associated Press
articles.description: A court in Moldova has placed former President Igor Dodon under 30-day house arrest.
articles.title: Moldova’s ex-president placed under 30-day house arrest

articles.author: EDITH M. LEDERER
articles.description: The resolution would have imposed tough new sanctions on North Korea for its spate of intercontinental ballistic missile launches that can be used to deliver nuclear weapons.
articles.title: China and Russia veto new UN sanctions on North Korea

articles.author: JILL LAWLESS
articles.description: British prosecutors say they have authorized police to charge actor Kevin Spacey with four counts of sexual assault against three men.
articles.title: Kevin Spacey to face 4 sex assault charges in Britain

articles.author: JADE LE DELEY
articles.description: Rape accusations against a newly named French minister have galvanized a movement aimed at exposing sexual misconduct in French politics and encouraging victims to speak out.
articles.title: French movement calls out sexual misconduct in politics

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: The mayor of Sievierodonetsk says the Ukrainian city is holding out, although a Russian reconnaissance and sabotage group went into a city hotel.
articles.title: Live updates | Mayor: Some 1,500 killed in Sievierodonetsk

articles.author: SUZAN FRASER
articles.description: Turkey’s leader has caused a stir by throwing a wrench in Sweden and Finland’s historic bid to join NATO, lashing out at fellow alliance member Greece and announcing plans for a new incursion into Syria.
articles.title: EXPLAINER: What Turkey’s Erdogan could gain in NATO debate

articles.author: ELENA BECATOROS and RICARDO MAZALAN
articles.description: Russia is pressing the West to lift sanctions over the war in Ukraine, seeking to shift the blame for a growing food crisis.

articles.description:
A recent statement released by French authorities has pledged France and Australia to “rebuild” a bilateral relationship – after accusing the previous Morrison government of a “breach of trust”. 

It comes as France accused its allies “of stabbing it in the back” – when Australia opted for nuclear-powered submarines to be built with US and British technology.

Following Australia’s federal election outcome, French President Emmanuel Macron called Prime Minister Anthony Albanese to congratulate him on his election win.

The full statement released by French authorities says:  

“After acknowledging the severe breach of trust following the decision of the previous prime minister, Scott Morrison to terminate the submarine contracts, the French president and Australia's prime minister have agreed to rebuild a bilateral relation based on trust and respect to jointly overcome global challenges, foremost among which is the climate emergency and the strategic challenges in the Indo-Pacific.”
articles.title: Albanese-Macron to mend Morrison’s ‘breach of trust’

articles.description:
ANU Department of Pacific Affairs Senior Fellow Graeme Smith says Foreign Minister Penny Wong has to offer the Pacific Islands that “China can’t offer”. 

Mr Smith said Ms Wong will bring pro-active foreign policy and will be an effective Foreign Minister. 

“What she’s got to do, and what she’s got to pitch …  is you have offer things that China can’t offer,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“Access to our labour markets … that’s what Pacific Islanders really want.”
articles.title: Penny Wong has to offer Pacific ‘what China can’t offer’

articles.description:
Jurors have finished hearing evidence from actors Johnny Depp and Amber Heard in their defamation trial.

Ms Heard returned to the stand for the last time ahead of closing arguments.

She claims she has been "harassed, humiliated and threatened" every day since accusing her former husband of physical and sexual abuse.

She was questioned if she was surprised by the number of people testifying against her.

British model Kate Moss denied rumours she was pushed down stairs by Mr Depp while they were dating.

Mr Depp has denied ever hitting Ms Heard.
articles.title: Johnny Depp-Amber Heard trial hears final evidence

articles.description:
British supermodel Kate Moss denying Amber Heard's claim her former boyfriend Johnny Depp abused her was the "quickest testimony" of the whole trial, says Mitry Lawyers' Richard Mitry.

Mr Mitry said Ms Moss' testimony was not pivotal to the outcome of the case but was important because it "directly refuted" Ms Heard's claim about Depp in her statement.

During Ms Heard’s testimony, she mentioned Kate Moss and a rumour that the actor once pushed the model down a flight of stairs, leaving the door open for Depp’s legal team to bring her in to take the stand.

Ms Moss denied rumours she was pushed down stairs by Mr Depp while they were dating.

"By Kate Moss not only denying that in all of three minutes, which is probably the quickest testimony in this whole trial, categorically stating good things about him – naturally it's going to help his case."
articles.title: ‘Quickest testimony’: Kate Moss denied Amber Heard’s claim ‘in all of three minutes’

articles.description:
Residents in the eastern Ukrainian city of Severodonetsk are eking out their remaining resources as the city bears the brunt of Russia's new offensive in the Donbas region.

Relentless shelling has meant residents are sheltering almost constantly in bunkers and basements – where hunger and disease are rife.
articles.title: Severodonetsk under renewed Russian attack

articles.description:
US reporter Chris Nguyen says it “remains to be seen” whether the US will enact stronger gun reform, following the horrific Texas school shooting. 

It comes after 19 children and two adults were killed at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde on Tuesday. 

“Many folks say, you know; enough is enough,” Mr Nguyen told Sky News Australia. 

“Others say, don’t politicise this.”
articles.title: US gun reform ‘remains to be seen’

articles.description:
Sky News Business Editor Ross Greenwood says China may be facing an economic slowdown and could be “even struggling to break even” as countries around the world grapple with rising prices and lack of economic demand. 

Mr Greenwood said a statement released by China’s Premier detailed how some economic indicators since March have “apparently declined, with difficulties greater even than shockwaves brought in by the outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020”.
articles.title: China facing prospect of economic slowdown

articles.description: Just one day after a tragic shooting claimed the lives of 19 kids and two adults, another student was seen holding a gun, headed towards a Texas high school.
articles.title: Texas student arrested with assault rifle day after tragic Uvalde shooting

articles.description:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says French President Emmanuel Macron “reached out very soon” after the 2022 federal election result was clear. 

“We’ve had an engagement already - I continue to engage with world leaders, I thank them for the very warm congratulations I have received,” Mr Albanese told Sky News Australia.
articles.title: Macron ‘reached out’ to Albanese ‘very soon’ election win

articles.description: A high school student in Texas has been arrested after he was seen holding an assault rifle and walking towards a high school in Richardson.
articles.title: Teen arrested ‘walking to school with rifle’

articles.description: Two sets of 10-year-old cousins and two teachers are among those who have been named as victims of a massacre at a Texas primary school that left 21 people dead.
articles.title: Students and teachers identified as victims of Texas school shooting

articles.description: Newly elected Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has had a “very positive” conversation with the French President in a sign relations between the two countries could be thawing.
articles.title: Albo’s private phone call with Macron

articles.description:
ASPI’s Michael Shoebridge says it is “good news” Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was congratulated by French President Emmanuel Macron, describing it as a “peace offering”.

Mr Shoebridge said it would be the “worst case” for Australia-France relations if Scott Morrison was re-elected.

“The worst case for Australia-France relations would have been Emmanuel Macron and Scott Morrison both being re-elected,” Mr Shoebridge told Sky News Australia. 

“Because unfortunately, it’s deeply personal between those two.”
articles.title: ‘Peace-offering’ in Australia-France relations

articles.description: Texas gubernatorial candidate Beto O’Rourke interrupted the state governor’s press conference on Wednesday, May 25, one day after a mass shooting left 21 people dead in Uvalde, Texas.
articles.title: Beto O’Rourke Confronts Texas Governor Greg Abbott at Uvalde Shooting Press Conference

articles.description: Gruesome footage has emerged allegedly revealing the carnage caused by a Ukrainian strike.
articles.title: Ukraine wipes out 14 elite Russian paratroopers in brutal strike

articles.description: At least 14 children and a teacher were killed in a mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, on Tuesday, Gov. Greg Abbott said. Photo: Marco Bello/Reuters
articles.title: Texas Elementary School Shooting Leaves at Least 15 Dead

articles.description:
President Joe Biden’s comments concerning China is either an “incoherent gaffe” or the US President “playing three dimensional chess”, says Lowy Institute Senior Fellow Richard McGregor.

Mr McGregor said President’s Biden’s comments are contrary to the current US policy towards China. 

“I think it tells us frankly that Mr Biden believes if that Taiwan were attacked, then the US would be involved,” he told Sky News Australia. 

“In theory though, that’s not the US policy. The US policy is to be much more, you know, keep China guessing.”
articles.title: Biden’s ‘incoherent gaffe’ over Taiwan

articles.description: The death toll for an ‘incomprehensible’ school shooting has increased to 18 children and a teacher, after Salvador Ramos ran into a building and opened fire.
articles.title: 18 students, teacher dead in horror school shooting in Texas

articles.description:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he was “very keen” to ensure Australia was represented at the Quad leaders’ summit in Tokyo. 

“To send a message to our partners in the United States, Japan and India that Australia continues to be strong supporters of the Quad,” he said while speaking to the media on Wednesday. 

Mr Albanese said the leaders discussed Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the nature of the Indo-Pacific region.
articles.title: Albanese ‘very keen’ to ensure Australia was represented at Quad meeting

articles.description: The death toll for the “horrific … incomprehensible” shooting which occurred at a primary school in Texas has increased to 18 children and three adults.
articles.title: 21 dead in horror school shooting

articles.description: The US is once again reeling from another horrific mass shooting which has left almost 20 people dead at Texas primary school.
articles.title: One word that proves America doesn’t get it

articles.description:
US President Joe Biden has spoken on the horrific tragedy involving up to 20 people being killed in a Texas school shooting. 

Mr Biden said the US needs to stand up to the gun lobby. 

“We have to act,” he said. 

“The idea that an 18-year old kid can walk into a gun-store and buy two assault weapons is just wrong … It’s just sick.”
articles.title: ‘It’s time to act’: Biden speaks out on tragic Texas shooting

articles.description:
New Zealand's Reserve Bank is holding its May cash rate decision today and it's expected to sharply increase interest rates.

Sky News Australia discussed the issue with Sky News Business reporter Edward Boyd.

"Reserve Bank in New Zealand has been lifting the cash rate sharply, it's at one and a half per cent right now, it's going to get up to two per cent probably by the end of today.

"We haven't actually seen inflation start to come down in New Zealand and that's a pretty good indicator for Australia as well. 

"Our Reserve Bank's lifting the cash rate and so far it hasn't really had any impact on inflation – I think they're going to need to lift it a lot more to start pushing down those inflationary pressures."
 
Mr Boyd said the RBA isn't expecting inflation to start declining until the middle of next year.

"It's going to peak at about six per cent headline inflation at the end of this year and slowly start to fall in mid 2023."
articles.title: NZ Reserve Bank expected to hike cash rate to two per cent

articles.description:
US President Joe Biden has pleaded for the country to act on gun "carnage", saying he was “struck” that mass shootings “rarely happen anywhere else across the world”. 

Mr Biden said he had been reflecting on his 17-hour flight –returning from the international Quad meeting with Australian and Asian leaders.

“What struck me was that this kind of mass shooting rarely happen anywhere else in the world,” he said. 

“Why are we willing to live with this carnage? Why do we keep letting this happen? Where in God’s name is our backbone … it’s time to act ... we have to do more."
articles.title: ‘Where in God’s name’: Biden pleas against gun ‘carnage’

articles.description: With the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan and a growing humanitarian crisis, the United States faces several policy options. While isolation is the usual response to an unwelcome regime change, engagement offers the only prospect to advance U.S. interests in the country, mainly counterterrorism and humanitarian relief.
articles.title: U.S. Policy Toward the Taliban: Engage, Isolate, or Oppose?

articles.description: Australia faces stiff geopolitical competition in Antarctica, and it's not just China and Russia with eyes on the prize.
articles.title: Not So Quiet on the Southern Front

articles.description: The demise of the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty opened an opportunity for the United States to develop and deploy ground-based intermediate-range missiles (GBIRMs). The Indo-Pacific has been considered a potential location for these missiles, but how U.S. allies will respond to overtures to host GBIRMs is not clear.
articles.title: What Is the Likelihood of U.S. Allies Hosting Intermediate-Range Missiles?

articles.description:
JPMorgan placed Bitcoin’s (BTC) fair price at $38,000, 28% higher than its current level of around $29,500, according to a note to clients the bank released on Wednesday.  “Last month’s crypto market correction looks more like a capitulation from last January/February and looking forward, we see an upside for bitcoin and crypto markets more generally,” the note reads.  Bank strategist Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou was the main author of this document.
A note from bank investors placed the fair value of bitcoin at the same level in February.  It was trading around $43,000 at the time.
Crypto has outmoded real estate as the preferred “alternative asset” of the bank, along with hedge funds, continues the note.  This mentioned:

“So far, there is little evidence of VC [venture capital] funding dries up after Terra’s collapse.  Of the $25 billion in VC funding year-to-date, nearly $4 billion has come after Terra.  Our best guess is that venture capital funding will continue and a long winter similar to 2018/2019 would be avoided.

Venture capital funding would be key to avoiding this crypto winter, he added.
On the same day, the great venture capitalist Andreessen Horowitz announced the closure of its fourth cryptocurrency fund at $4.5 billion.  Also on Wednesday, crypto-focused venture capital firm NGC Ventures launched its third blockchain fund with $100 million raised from investors such as Babel Finance, Huobi Ventures and Nexo Ventures.
JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon has repeatedly said expressed his personal antipathy to cryptocurrency, going so far as to call it a fraud, but the bank itself has taken a more practical stance.  This becomes the first major bankin the Metaverse earlier this year.  Dimon praised crypto for its ease of cross-border payment.

Source Link
articles.title: JPMorgan puts BTC fair price at $38,000, declares crypto a preferred alternative asset

articles.description:
Angela Lansbury, acclaimed and adored star of stage, film and television, will be honored this year with a special Tony Lifetime Achievement Award.
Lansbury, 96, who has already won five competitions Tony Awardwill receive the lifetime achievement award on June 12, when this year’s ceremony will take place at Radio City Music Hall and air on CBS.
Lansbury first appeared on Broadway in 1957, in a farce titled “Hotel Paradiso,” and in 1964 she starred in her first Broadway musical, “Anyone Can Whistle,” a flop most remembered for. that the songwriter was Stephen Sondheim.


She was already a three-time Oscar nominee, including for ‘The Manchurian Candidate’ in 1962, when she landed her role on Broadway, starring as the free-spirited lead character in 1966’s ‘Mame’. She won his first Tony Award for this performance.


She starred in several Sondheim musicals, winning Tony Awards for playing the theater’s most famous stage mother, Momma Rose, in “Gypsy,” as well as the scheming pastry chef owner Mrs. Lovett in ” Sweeney Todd”.  His most recent Tony nomination, in 2010, was for his work in a revival of another Sondheim musical, “A little night music.”
Lansbury also won Tony Awards for a short-lived musical titled “Dear World” and a revival of Noël Coward’s play “joyful spirit.”
Her last Broadway appearance was in a 2012 revival of “The best man», a play by Gore Vidal.
Lansbury also had a long career in film – she memorably voiced Mrs. Potts in ‘Beauty and the Beast’ – and in television, where she was the longtime star of ‘Murder, She Wrote’.
The Tony Awards are set to begin June 12 at 7 p.m. EST with an hour-long segment airing on Paramount+ hosted by Darren Criss and Julianne Hough, followed at 8 p.m. EST by a three-hour segment aired on CBS hosted by Ariana DeBose.

Source Link
articles.title: Angela Lansbury to receive Tony Lifetime Achievement Award

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
One night in May 1997, in Tacoma, Washington, Kimonti Carter machine-gunned a car he believed to be carrying rival gang members.  It wasn’t – not that it should matter.  One of the five passengers in the car, a student, Corey Pittman, 19, was killed.  Carter, who had just turned 18, was sentenced to life in prison.
In director Gilda Sheppard’s sympathetic documentary “Since I Been Down”, punishment is also a crime.
Filled with archival visuals of Tacoma in the late 1980s and 1990s, when crack cocaine and gang violence took their toll, the documentary’s greatest strength is its listening tour, with Carter as the main guide.


Because Carter fired from a car, he was charged with aggravated first-degree murder, which carries an automatic mandatory life sentence.  (His reconviction hearing is scheduled for July 8.) He is not the only one facing harsh prison terms.  Washington state’s three-stroke sentence (which abolished parole in 1984) can be particularly difficult for young offenders.


Over the decades, Carter expressed remorse, but it was his role as a beneficiary and leader of inmate-led initiatives, the Black Prisoner Collective and TEACH, or Taking Education and Changing History, that suggests a transformation.
Other inmates here share their insights, as do two former detectives, some former gang members, and the mothers of victims and perpetrators.  One former inmate, Tonya Wilson, who served 17 years, is particularly insightful about the personal and societal forces that led to her incarceration.
Another prisoner said, “We say that a lot of the answers that people are looking for in society will be found in prison.
“We caused pain,” said this inmate, “mainly because we are in pain.”
Far from looking like an excuse, in “Since I Been Down”, this observation sounds like a way to take account and change.
Since I’ve been down
Unclassified.  Duration: 1h45.  Rent or buy on Amazon, google play and other streaming platforms and pay TV operators.

Source Link
articles.title: 'Since I Was Shot' Review: Crime and Punishment

articles.description:
Jen Psaki, who became famous as President Biden’s first White House press secretary, presiding over 200 briefings and earning TikTok stardom for his sometimes thorny exchanges with reporters, will join cable news channel MSNBC later this year.
She will serve as a political analyst throughout this year’s midterm elections and during the 2024 presidential campaign, the channel said on Tuesday.  She is also set to host a show starting next year on a streaming-only channel, MSNBC on Peacock.
Ms Psaki’s last day in the West Wing was May 13 and her appearance on television news was widely expected.  Speculations on his potential work at MSNBC started this year while she was still presiding over the White House pulpit.  Ms Psaki said at the time that she adhered to ethical guidelines while discussing future job prospects.
She is the second major hire by MSNBC from the Biden administration. Symone D. Sanders, a former spokeswoman for Vice President Kamala Harris, hosts a weekend show for the network.  Ms. Psaki said in a statement provided by MSNBC that her program would focus on “factual, thoughtful conversations about the big issues that matter to people across the country.”


MSNBC is popular with Democrats and left-leaning viewers, and its election and main-evening coverage already includes savvy hosts like Rachel Maddow and Nicolle Wallace.  Now its viewers will receive real-time commentary from a key member of Mr. Biden’s first term inner circle.
Ms. Psaki previously worked as an on-air contributor to CNN.  Prior to that, she served as White House Communications Director for former President Barack Obama and Chief Spokesperson for former Secretary of State John Kerry.

Source Link
articles.title: Jen Psaki joins MSNBC as host and commentator

Some Asian elephants are a little shy about their eating habits.  They sneak into dumpsites near human settlements at the edge of their forest habitats and quickly gobble up trash – plastic utensils, wrappers and all.  But their guilty pleasure for fast food is traveling with them – elephants carry plastic and other human waste deep into the forests of parts of India.
“When they defecate, the plastic comes out of the feces and settles in the forest,” said Gitanjali Katlam, an ecology researcher in India.
While much research has been conducted on the spread of plastics from human pollution in the world’s oceans and seas, much less is known about how this waste moves with terrestrial wildlife.  But elephants are important seed dispersers, and research published this month in the Journal for …

Mercury is meaningless.  It is a bizarre piece of rock with a composition that is different from its neighboring rocky planets.
“It’s way too dense,” said David Rothery, a planetary scientist at the Open University in England.
Most of the planet closest to the sun is occupied by its core.  It lacks an Earth-thick mantle, and no one really knows why. A possibility is that the planet was much larger – perhaps twice its current mass or more.  Billions of years ago, this nascent proto-Mercury, or super Mercury, could have been hit by a large object, stripping away its outer layers and leaving behind the rest we see.
Although this is a good idea, there has never been any direct evidence for it.  But some researchers think they’ve found something.  At work presented at the Lunar and Planetary Sc…

Dear stumbled,
My question is about airlines changing routes, a huge frustration for me since returning to travel after a pandemic break.  I’ll book a direct flight at the right time, then get an email days or weeks later with an inconvenient time change or an extra layover or both.  The worst was when I was planning a trip with my daughter to Tampa, Florida.  In January, I booked a direct flight on Southwest Airlines that departed Hartford, Connecticut, at 12:30 p.m. on April 17 and arrived in Tampa three hours later.  .  Perfect.  But on February 15, Southwest sent me an e-mail telling me that they had transferred me to a 6:15 p.m. flight with an almost three-hour layover in Nashville, bringing me to Tampa at 1:10 a.m.!  Why is it OK?  It’s like I bought a nice Subaru Forester and they d…

DALLAS — Jason Kidd, coach of the Mavericks, had a concise message for his players ahead of Game 3 of the NBA Western Conference Finals on Sunday night.
Open shots, he reminded them in the locker room, are easier to make than contested shots, so get in the paint and draw Golden State defenders.  Do that, and the space will open up around the perimeter.
“Attack, attack, attack,” Kidd said, his voice betraying great urgency.  “Make them work.”
It was a smart strategy, and sure enough, it worked.  The Mavericks generated a respectable number of 3-point clean looks.  The problem?  They couldn’t do much.  Luka Doncic, the team’s star point guard, offered a summary.

Dwayne Haskins24, the Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback and a former Ohio State standout, was intoxicated when he was hit and killed by a truck on a Florida highway in April, according to a toxicology report released by the Broward County, Fla., Medical Examiner’s Office on Monday.
In two samples, Haskins had a blood alcohol concentration of 0.20% and 0.24% at the time of his autopsy, according to the report, more than double the legal limit of 0.08% in Florida.  Ketamine, a sedative that is also considered a recreational hallucinogen, was also found in Haskins’ system, according to the report.
Through an attorney, Haskins’ wife Kalabrya in a statement Monday asked for patience and privacy.

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
But Osaka is uncertain, although she may travel to Berlin to play in the new grass-court event that will count towards her ranking.
“Overall, I feel like I’m going to stop telling myself I’m bad on these surfaces,” she said of grass and clay, “and at the place, keep your head down and keep working really hard, because I think that’s what I’ve been doing all year. I can’t expect everything to happen at once. I hope so that, gradually, I will have the results I want.
So far, she has four Grand Slam singles titles, all on hard courts, most recently at the 2021 Australian Open about 16 months ago.  The pecking order changes and is not in his favor.  After breaking down in tears mid-match at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., in March after a heckler rocked her in a second-round loss, she bounced back to reach the final of the Miami Open, where Swiatek beat her, 6-4, 6-0.
Osaka, who plays for Japan and is based in the United States, remains one of the biggest stars in the sport and the highest paid female athlete in the world by far.  She has enough lucrative long-term endorsement deals to justify recently break up with IMG to set up his own management agency with Stuart Duguid, his agent.
But Osaka will be ranked around world No. 40 after Roland Garros, and while his portfolio looks strong in redwood, how does that affect the bottom line and his place in the sporting landscape if a young player like Swiatek takes the real control of the sport and younger, possibly hungrier players like Anisimova continue to dominate Osaka at the start of major tournaments?
To what extent, in the age of social media, should results and stardom continue to align once the millions of followers are already acquired?
Osaka, left ankle wrapped, seemed genuinely determined to change her luck on Monday, digging into the corners and maintaining positive energy almost to the end.  But Anisimova has been more consistent on serve and more devastating from the baseline and, crucially, on the returns.

Source Link
articles.title: French Open: Osaka fights on clay, Anisimova propels the striker

articles.author: noreply@blogger.com (Newsrust)
articles.description:
In less than a month, the crypto mining bill in the Russian parliament lost several key points, such as the obligation for mining operators to register in a special register and a one-year tax amnesty for all those who registered.  According to the reasoning, the previous project would result in federal budget losses. 
The new draft law “On Mining in the Russian Federation”, dated May 20, appeared in the database of the lower house of the Russian parliament, the State Duma.  The document has several significant changes from the previous version, present by the co-sponsors on April 29. 
While the text remains unchanged in general, the new draft misses the subsection on a register of mining operators, which companies should register in order to continue their work.  In the latest version, to start mining, crypto mining companies must register as sole proprietor or self-employed.  Companies would follow a standard procedure for company registration. 
Related: Russia To Include Crypto In Its Tax Code: Here’s What The Rules Could Look Like
Another correction swept away the promise of tax amnesty in the first year of registration.  The grace period would apply to the clearance of mining equipment, any profits made before the law was passed, and any violations of strict limits on money transfers abroad adopted by the Russian government on March 8. .  local media, in its review of the project, the legal department of the State Duma critical registration and tax amnesty initiatives, stating that they could “eventually incur costs on the federal budget”.
On April 7, the head of the State Duma’s Financial Markets Committee, Anatoly Aksakov, revealed that changes to the federal tax code regarding crypto should be adopted. by the end of summer parliamentary session.  It is unclear if they would include specifications regarding mining.

Source Link
articles.title: Updated Russian Crypto Mining Bill Reduces Tax Amnesty for Bitcoin Miners

articles.description:
In this File photo from 2020, a US soldier sits at a Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS) after an artillery live fire event by the US Army Europe's 41st Field Artillery Brigade in Germany.    
CNN: US preparing to approve advanced long-range rocket system for Ukraine 
Washington (CNN)The Biden administration is preparing to step up the kind of weaponry it is offering Ukraine by sending advanced, long-range rocket systems that are now the top request from Ukrainian officials, multiple officials say. 
The administration is leaning toward sending the systems as part of a larger package of military and security assistance to Ukraine, which could be announced as soon as next week. 
Senior Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelensky, have pleaded in recent weeks for the US and its allies to provide the Multiple Launch Rocket System, or MLRS. The US-made weapon systems can fire a barrage of rockets hundreds of kilometers — much farther than any of the systems Ukraine already has — which the Ukrainians argue could be a gamechanger in their war against Russia.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: These rockets can hit deep into Russia. This will be seen by Moscow as a major escalation .... US warns Ukraine about escalation – media (RT).
articles.title: U.S. To Approve Sending To Ukraine The Multiple Launch Rocket System, Or MLRS

U.S. Marines load an M777 towed 155 mm howitzer into the cargo hold of a U.S. Air Force C-17 Globemaster III transport plane, to be delivered in Europe for Ukrainian forces, at March Air Reserve Base, California, U.S. April 21, 2022. Picture taken April 21, 2022. U.S. Marine Corps/Cpl. Austin Fraley/Handout via REUTERS.   
Reuters: Exclusive-U.S. and Ukraine Discuss Danger of Escalation as New Arms Extend Kyiv's Reach 
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - As the United States and its allies provide Ukraine with increasingly sophisticated arms, Washington has held discussions with Kyiv about the danger of escalation if it strikes deep inside Russia, U.S. and diplomatic officials tell Reuters. 
The behind-the-scenes discussions, which are highly sensitive and have not been previously reported, do not put explicit geographic restrictions on the use of weapons supplied to Ukrainian forces. 
But the conversations have sought to reach a shared understanding of the risk of escalation, three U.S. officials and diplomatic sources said.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: These are the weapons that Ukraine currently want .... Explained: The 'Game-Changer' Weapon Ukraine Wants, U.S. Resists Sending (Newsweek).
articles.title: Washington Raises Concerns With Kyiv On Using U.S. Weapons To Strike Targets Deep In Russia

articles.description:
OilPrice.com: Here's How Russian Crude Is Finding Its Way To Customers 
* Refinitiv Eikon: Greece has emerged as a new hub for Russian oil via ship-to-ship (STS) loadings. 
* Vortexa: Russia has been increasing fuel exports to Greece, with shipments set to jump to about 2.5 million barrels. 
* Trading Russian crude and oil products remain legal for now. 
Small tankers and ship-to-ship transfers are being used to keep the flow of Russian oil to China steady, Bloomberg reported this week, citing sources from the brokering industry.
Typically, the report notes, Russian ESPO crude is shipped directly to China. But lately, buyers are opting for loading the crude on small tankers and shipping it to South Korean waters, from where it is loaded onto supertankers and then taken to China. 
According to Bloomberg’s sources, the change is a result of reprioritization among buyers as shipowners avoid loading Russian oil because of Western sanctions. Currently, almost all of the ESPO available for sale is going to China.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: As high as oil prices are right now, I shudder when I think on what would happen if all Russia oil and energy exports are banned. The cost of oil would then go through the roof. 
This Is How Russian Oil Is Finding Its Way To Customers   
Russia's Oil Export Loophole Runs Through Greece -- OilPrice.com  
China is shuttling small ships to tankers at sea to transport cheap Russian oil amid sanctions, report says -- Insider  
Rare Ship-to-Ship Transfers Keep Oil Moving From Russia to China -- Bloomberg  
An oil trading company named Bellatrix is one of the under-the-radar firms that has taken over from the big names in shipping Russian crude -- Insider
articles.title: This Is How Russian Oil Is Finding Its Way To Customers

articles.description:
Saudi oil production hit 10.3 million barrels in April. Photo credit should read MARWAN NAAMANI/AFP   
Rigzone/Bloomberg: Saudi Arabia Making $1B From Oil Exports Every Day  
Saudi Arabia’s oil exports reached $30 billion in March, the highest in at least six years, driven by a rally in oil prices and rising production. 
The value of crude exports, now almost $1 billion a day, increased by 123% year on year, the kingdom’s statistics office said. 
Saudi Arabia’s crude production rose to 10.3 million barrels a day in March, with Brent oil prices averaging $112 a barrel. Prices have jumped almost 50% this year, mostly due to the fallout of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. 
The higher revenues helped the kingdom post a 57.5 billion riyal ($15 billion) budget surplus between January and March. It will be one of the fastest-growing large economies in the world this year, according to the International Monetary Fund. 
Read more ....   
Update #1: Saudi Arabia oil exports soared to the most since 2016 in Q1 thanks crude prices above $100 a barrel and higher production (Insider)  
Update #2: Saudi Arabia Tucks Away Billions in Oil Money for Next Year (Bloomberg)   
WNU Editor: I would not be surprised if they will be making more per day in the coming months as oil prices continue to rise.
articles.title: Saudi Arabia Is Now Making $1B From Oil Exports Every Day

articles.description:
New York Times: Documents Shed Light on Secret U.S. Plans for Apocalyptic Scenarios 
WASHINGTON — Newly disclosed documents have shed a crack of light on secret executive branch plans for apocalyptic scenarios — like the aftermath of a nuclear attack — when the president may activate wartime powers for national security emergencies. 
Until now, public knowledge of what the government put into those classified directives, which invoke emergency and wartime powers granted by Congress or otherwise claimed by presidents, has been limited to declassified descriptions of those developed in the early Cold War. 
In that era, they included steps like imposing martial law, rounding up people deemed dangerous and censoring news from abroad.   
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: Here are some of the measures that the US government will impose in an extreme emergency .... Presidential Emergency Action Documents (Brennan Center For Justice).
articles.title: Recently Released Documents Show What The U.S. Goverment Will Do If An Apocalypse Occurs

Women move food from a distribution site on the outskirts of Herat, Afghanistan in 2021. © WFP/Marco Di Lauro   
Afghanistan: Nearly 20 million going hungry  
Nearly 20 million people in Afghanistan – almost half the population – are facing acute hunger, humanitarians warned in a UN-backed report, published on Monday. 
The latest Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis for the country also revealed a pocket of “catastrophic” levels of food insecurity in the northeast, affecting thousands. 
The analysis was conducted in January and February by partners who include the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), sister agency the World Food Programme (WFP), and many non-governmental organizations.    
Read more ....   
WNU Editor: The UN has updated its report .... 1.1 million Afghan children could face severe malnutrition (ABC News/AP).
articles.title: UN Report Says Nearly 20 Million Afghans Are Facing Acute Hunger
